text: There was once a man in the land of Uz whose name was Job. That man was blameless and upright, one who feared God and turned away from evil.
speaker: Narrator

text: There were born to him seven sons and three daughters.
speaker: Narrator

text: He had seven thousand sheep, three thousand camels, five hundred yoke of oxen, five hundred donkeys, and very many servants, so that this man was the greatest of all the people of the East.
speaker: Narrator

text: His sons used to go and hold feasts in one another’s houses in turn, and they would send and invite their three sisters to eat and drink with them.
speaker: Narrator

text: And when the feast days had run their course, Job would send and sanctify them, and he would rise early in the morning and offer burnt offerings according to the number of them all, for Job said, “It may be that my children have sinned and cursed God in their hearts.” This is what Job always did.
speaker: Narrator

text: One day the heavenly beings came to present themselves before the Lord, and the accuser also came among them.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to the accuser, “Where have you come from?” The accuser answered the Lord, “From going to and fro on the earth and from walking up and down on it.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to the accuser, “Have you considered my servant Job? There is no one like him on the earth, a blameless and upright man who fears God and turns away from evil.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the accuser answered the Lord, “Does Job fear God for nothing?
speaker: Narrator

text: Have you not put a fence around him and his house and all that he has, on every side? You have blessed the work of his hands, and his possessions have increased in the land.
speaker: Narrator

text: But stretch out your hand now, and touch all that he has, and he will curse you to your face.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to the accuser, “Very well, all that he has is in your power; only do not stretch out your hand against him!” So the accuser went out from the presence of the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: One day when his sons and daughters were eating and drinking wine in the eldest brother’s house,
speaker: Narrator

text: a messenger came to Job and said, “The oxen were plowing and the donkeys were feeding beside them,
speaker: Narrator

text: and the Sabeans fell on them and carried them off and killed the servants with the edge of the sword; I alone have escaped to tell you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: While he was still speaking, another came and said, “The fire of God fell from heaven and burned up the sheep and the servants and consumed them; I alone have escaped to tell you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: While he was still speaking, another came and said, “The Chaldeans formed three columns, made a raid on the camels and carried them off, and killed the servants with the edge of the sword; I alone have escaped to tell you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: While he was still speaking, another came and said, “Your sons and daughters were eating and drinking wine in their eldest brother’s house,
speaker: Narrator

text: and suddenly a great wind came across the desert, struck the four corners of the house, and it fell on the young people, and they are dead; I alone have escaped to tell you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Job arose, tore his robe, shaved his head, and fell on the ground and worshiped.
speaker: Narrator

text: He said, “Naked I came from my mother’s womb, and naked shall I return there; the Lord gave, and the Lord has taken away; blessed be the name of the Lord.”
speaker: Narrator

text: In all this Job did not sin or charge God with wrongdoing.
speaker: Narrator

text: One day the heavenly beings came to present themselves before the Lord, and the accuser also came among them to present himself before the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to the accuser, “Where have you come from?” The accuser answered the Lord, “From going to and fro on the earth and from walking up and down on it.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to the accuser, “Have you considered my servant Job? There is no one like him on the earth, a blameless and upright man who fears God and turns away from evil. He still persists in his integrity, although you incited me against him, to destroy him for no reason.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the accuser answered the Lord, “Skin for skin! All that the man has he will give for his life.
speaker: Narrator

text: But stretch out your hand now and touch his bone and his flesh, and he will curse you to your face.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to the accuser, “Very well, he is in your power; only spare his life.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So the accuser went out from the presence of the Lord and inflicted loathsome sores on Job from the sole of his foot to the crown of his head.
speaker: Narrator

text: Job took a potsherd with which to scrape himself and sat among the ashes.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then his wife said to him, “Do you still persist in your integrity? Curse God and die.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But he said to her, “You speak as any foolish woman would speak. Shall we receive good from God and not receive evil?” In all this Job did not sin with his lips.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now when Job’s three friends heard of all these troubles that had come upon him, each of them set out from his home—Eliphaz the Temanite, Bildad the Shuhite, and Zophar the Naamathite. They met together to go and console and comfort him.
speaker: Narrator

text: When they saw him from a distance, they did not recognize him, and they raised their voices and wept aloud; they tore their robes and threw dust in the air upon their heads.
speaker: Narrator

text: They sat with him on the ground seven days and seven nights, and no one spoke a word to him, for they saw that his suffering was very great.
speaker: Narrator

text: After this Job opened his mouth and cursed the day of his birth.
speaker: Narrator

text: Job said:
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Let the day perish in which I was born,
    and the night that said,
    ‘A male is conceived.’
speaker: Narrator

text:
Let that day be darkness!
    May God above not seek it
    or light shine on it.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator
Narrator

text:
Yes, let that night be barren;
    let no joyful cry be heard in it.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Let those curse it who curse the Sea,
    those who are skilled to rouse up Leviathan.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
because it did not shut the doors of my mother’s womb
    and hide trouble from my eyes.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Why did I not die at birth,
    come forth from the womb and expire?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Why were there knees to receive me
    or breasts for me to suck?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Now I would be lying down and quiet;
    I would be asleep; then I would be at rest
speaker: Narrator

text:
with kings and counselors of the earth
    who rebuild ruins for themselves,
speaker: Narrator

text:
or with princes who have gold,
    who fill their houses with silver.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Or why was I not buried like a stillborn child,
    like an infant that never sees the light?
speaker: Narrator

text:
There the wicked cease from troubling,
    and there the weary are at rest.
speaker: Narrator

text:
There the prisoners are at ease together;
    they do not hear the voice of the taskmaster.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The small and the great are there,
    and the slaves are free from their masters.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Why is light given to one in misery
    and life to the bitter in soul,
speaker: Narrator

text:
who long for death, but it does not come,
    and dig for it more than for hidden treasures;
speaker: Narrator

text:
who rejoice exceedingly
    and are glad when they find the grave?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Why is light given to one who cannot see the way,
    whom God has fenced in?
speaker: Narrator

text:
For my sighing comes like my bread,
    and my groanings are poured out like water.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Truly the thing that I fear comes upon me,
    and what I dread befalls me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I am not at ease, nor am I quiet;
    I have no rest, but trouble comes.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Eliphaz the Temanite answered:
speaker: Narrator

text:
“If one ventures a word with you, will you be offended?
    But who can keep from speaking?
speaker: Narrator

text:
See, you have instructed many;
    you have strengthened the weak hands.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Your words have supported those who were stumbling,
    and you have made firm the feeble knees.
speaker: Narrator

text:
But now it has come to you, and you are impatient;
    it touches you, and you are dismayed.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Is not your fear of God your confidence
    and the integrity of your ways your hope?
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Think now, who that was innocent ever perished?
    Or where were the upright cut off?
speaker: Narrator

text:
As I have seen, those who plow iniquity
    and sow trouble reap the same.
speaker: Narrator

text:
By the breath of God they perish,
    and by the blast of his anger they are consumed.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The roar of the lion, the voice of the fierce lion,
    and the teeth of the young lions are broken.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The strong lion perishes for lack of prey,
    and the whelps of the lioness are scattered.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Now a word came stealing to me;
    my ear received the whisper of it.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Amid thoughts from visions of the night,
    when deep sleep falls on mortals,
speaker: Narrator

text:
dread came upon me and trembling,
    which made all my bones shake.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A spirit glided past my face;
    the hair of my flesh bristled.
speaker: Narrator

text:
It stood still,
    but I could not discern its appearance.
A form was before my eyes;
    there was silence; then I heard a voice:
speaker: Narrator

text:
‘Can mortals be righteous before God?
    Can humans be pure before their Maker?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Even in his servants he puts no trust,
    and his angels he charges with error;
speaker: Narrator

text:
how much more those who live in houses of clay,
    whose foundation is in the dust,
    who are crushed like a moth.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Between morning and evening they are destroyed;
    they perish forever without any regarding it.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Their tent cord is plucked up within them,
    and they die devoid of wisdom.’
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Call now; is there anyone who will answer you?
To which of the holy ones will you turn?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Surely vexation kills the fool,
    and jealousy slays the simple.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I have seen fools taking root,
    but suddenly I cursed their dwelling.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Their children are far from safety,
    they are crushed in the gate,
    and there is no one to deliver them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The hungry eat their harvest,
    and they take it even out of the thorns,
    and the thirsty pant after their wealth.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For misery does not come from the earth,
    nor does trouble sprout from the ground,
speaker: Narrator

text:
but humans are born to trouble
    just as sparks fly upward.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“As for me, I would seek God,
    and to God I would commit my cause.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He does great things and unsearchable,
    marvelous things without number.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He gives rain on the earth
    and sends waters on the fields;
speaker: Narrator

text:
he sets on high those who are lowly,
    and those who mourn are lifted to safety.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He frustrates the devices of the crafty,
    so that their hands achieve no success.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He takes the wise in their own craftiness,
    and the schemes of the wily are brought to a quick end.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They meet with darkness in the daytime
    and grope at noonday as in the night.
speaker: Narrator

text:
But he saves the needy from the sword of their mouth,
    from the hand of the mighty.
speaker: Narrator

text:
So the poor have hope,
    and injustice shuts its mouth.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“How happy is the one whom God reproves;
    therefore do not despise the discipline of the Almighty.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For he wounds, but he binds up;
    he strikes, but his hands heal.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He will deliver you from six troubles;
    in seven no harm shall touch you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
In famine he will redeem you from death
    and in war from the power of the sword.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You shall be hidden from the scourge of the tongue
    and shall not fear destruction when it comes.
speaker: Narrator

text:
At destruction and famine you shall laugh
    and shall not fear the wild animals of the earth.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For you shall be in league with the stones of the field,
    and the wild animals shall be at peace with you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You shall know that your tent is safe;
    you shall inspect your fold and miss nothing.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You shall know that your descendants will be many
    and your offspring like the grass of the earth.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You shall come to your grave in ripe old age,
    as a shock of grain comes up to the threshing floor in its season.
speaker: Narrator

text:
See, we have searched this out; it is true.
    Hear, and know it for yourself.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Job answered:
speaker: Narrator

text:
“O that my vexation were weighed
    and all my calamity laid in the balances!
speaker: Narrator

text:
For then it would be heavier than the sand of the sea;
    therefore my words have been rash.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
Does the wild ass bray over its grass
    or the ox low over its fodder?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Can that which is tasteless be eaten without salt,
    or is there any flavor in the juice of mallows?
speaker: Narrator

text:
My appetite refuses to touch them;
    they are like food that is loathsome to me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“O that I might have my request
    and that God would grant my desire,
speaker: Narrator

text:
that it would please God to crush me,
    that he would let loose his hand and cut me off!
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
What is my strength, that I should wait?
    And what is my end, that I should be patient?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Is my strength the strength of stones,
    or is my flesh bronze?
speaker: Narrator

text:
In truth I have no help in me,
    and any resource is driven from me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Those who withhold kindness from a friend
    forsake the fear of the Almighty.
speaker: Narrator

text:
My companions are treacherous like a torrent bed,
    like swollen streams that pass away,
speaker: Narrator

text:
that run dark with ice,
    turbid with melting snow.
speaker: Narrator

text:
In time of heat they disappear;
    when it is hot, they vanish from their place.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The caravans turn aside from their course;
    they go up into the waste and perish.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The caravans of Tema look;
    the travelers of Sheba hope.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They are disappointed because they were confident;
    they come there and are confounded.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Such you have now become to me;
    you see my calamity and are afraid.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Have I said, ‘Make me a gift’?
    Or, ‘From your wealth offer a bribe for me’?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Or, ‘Save me from an opponent’s hand’?
    Or, ‘Ransom me from the hand of oppressors’?
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Teach me, and I will be silent;
    make me understand how I have gone wrong.
speaker: Narrator

text:
How forceful are honest words!
    But your reproof, what does it reprove?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Do you think that you can reprove words,
    as if the speech of the desperate were wind?
speaker: Narrator

text:
You would even cast lots over the orphan
    and bargain over your friend.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“But now, be pleased to look at me,
    for I will not lie to your face.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Turn, I pray; let no wrong be done.
    Turn now; my vindication is at stake.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Is there any wrong on my tongue?
    Cannot my taste discern calamity?
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Do not human beings have a hard service on earth,
    and are not their days like the days of a laborer?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Like a slave who longs for the shadow,
    and like laborers who look for their wages,
speaker: Narrator

text:
so I am allotted months of emptiness,
    and nights of misery are apportioned to me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
When I lie down I say, ‘When shall I rise?’
    But the night is long,
    and I am full of tossing until dawn.
speaker: Narrator

text:
My flesh is clothed with worms and dirt;
    my skin hardens, then breaks out again.
speaker: Narrator

text:
My days are swifter than a weaver’s shuttle
    and come to their end without hope.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Remember that my life is a breath;
    my eye will never again see good.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The eye that beholds me will see me no more;
    while your eyes are upon me, I shall be gone.
speaker: Narrator

text:
As the cloud fades and vanishes,
    so those who go down to Sheol do not come up;
speaker: Narrator

text:
they return no more to their houses,
    nor do their places know them any more.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
Am I the Sea or the Dragon
    that you set a guard over me?
speaker: Narrator

text:
When I say, ‘My bed will comfort me,
    my couch will ease my complaint,’
speaker: Narrator

text:
then you scare me with dreams
    and terrify me with visions,
speaker: Narrator

text:
so that I would choose strangling
    and death rather than this body.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I loathe my life; I would not live forever.
    Let me alone, for my days are a breath.
speaker: Narrator

text:
What are humans, that you make so much of them,
    that you set your mind on them,
speaker: Narrator

text:
visit them every morning,
    test them every moment?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Will you not look away from me for a while,
    let me alone until I swallow my spittle?
speaker: Narrator

text:
If I sin, what do I do to you, you watcher of humanity?
    Why have you made me your target?
    Why have I become a burden to you?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Why do you not pardon my transgression
    and take away my iniquity?
For now I shall lie in the earth;
    you will seek me, but I shall not be.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Bildad the Shuhite answered:
speaker: Narrator

text:
“How long will you say these things
    and the words of your mouth be a great wind?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Does God pervert justice?
    Or does the Almighty pervert the right?
speaker: Narrator

text:
If your children sinned against him,
    he delivered them into the power of their transgression.
speaker: Narrator

text:
If you will seek God
    and make supplication to the Almighty,
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
Though your beginning was small,
    your latter days will be very great.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“For inquire now of bygone generations
    and consider what their ancestors have found,
speaker: Narrator

text:
for we are but of yesterday, and we know nothing,
    for our days on earth are but a shadow.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Will they not teach you and tell you
    and utter words out of their understanding?
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Can papyrus grow where there is no marsh?
    Can reeds flourish where there is no water?
speaker: Narrator

text:
While yet in flower and not cut down,
    they wither before any other plant.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Such are the paths of all who forget God;
    the hope of the godless shall perish.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Their confidence is gossamer,
    a spider’s house their trust.
speaker: Narrator

text:
If one leans against its house, it will not stand;
    if one lays hold of it, it will not endure.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The wicked thrive before the sun,
    and their shoots spread over the garden.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Their roots twine around the stoneheap;
    they live among the rocks.
speaker: Narrator

text:
If they are destroyed from their place,
    then it will deny them, saying, ‘I have never seen you.’
speaker: Narrator

text:
See, these are their happy ways,
    and out of the earth still others will spring.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“See, God will not reject the blameless,
    nor take the hand of evildoers.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He will yet fill your mouth with laughter
    and your lips with shouts of joy.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Those who hate you will be clothed with shame,
    and the tent of the wicked will be no more.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Job answered:
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Indeed, I know that this is so,
    but how can a mortal be just before God?
speaker: Narrator

text:
If one wished to contend with him,
    one could not answer him once in a thousand.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He is wise in heart and mighty in strength;
    who has resisted him and succeeded?
speaker: Narrator

text:
He removes mountains, and they do not know it
    when he overturns them in his anger;
speaker: Narrator

text:
he shakes the earth out of its place,
    and its pillars tremble;
speaker: Narrator

text:
he commands the sun, and it does not rise;
    he seals up the stars;
speaker: Narrator

text:
he alone stretched out the heavens
    and trampled the waves of the Sea;
speaker: Narrator

text:
he made the Bear and Orion,
    the Pleiades and the chambers of the south;
speaker: Narrator

text:
he does great things beyond understanding
    and marvelous things without number.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Look, he passes by me, and I do not see him;
    he moves on, but I do not perceive him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He snatches away; who can stop him?
    Who will say to him, ‘What are you doing?’
speaker: Narrator

text:
“God will not turn back his anger;
    the helpers of Rahab bowed beneath him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
How then can I answer him,
    choosing my words with him?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Though I am innocent, I cannot answer him;
    I must appeal to my accuser for my right.
speaker: Narrator

text:
If I summoned him and he answered me,
    I do not believe that he would listen to my voice.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For he crushes me with a tempest
    and multiplies my wounds without cause;
speaker: Narrator

text:
he will not let me get my breath
    but fills me with bitterness.
speaker: Narrator

text:
If it is a contest of strength, he is the strong one!
    If it is a matter of justice, who can summon him?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Though I am innocent, my own mouth would condemn me;
    though I am blameless, he would prove me perverse.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I am blameless; I do not know myself;
    I loathe my life.
speaker: Narrator

text:
It is all one; therefore I say,
    ‘He destroys both the blameless and the wicked.’
speaker: Narrator

text:
When disaster brings sudden death,
    he mocks at the calamity of the innocent.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
“My days are swifter than a runner;
    they flee away; they see no good.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They go by like skiffs of reed,
    like an eagle swooping on the prey.
speaker: Narrator

text:
If I say, ‘I will forget my complaint;
    I will put off my sad countenance and be of good cheer,’
speaker: Narrator

text:
I become afraid of all my suffering,
    for I know you will not hold me innocent.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I shall be condemned;
    why then do I labor in vain?
speaker: Narrator

text:
If I wash myself with soap
    and cleanse my hands with lye,
speaker: Narrator

text:
yet you will plunge me into filth,
    and my own clothes will abhor me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For he is not a mortal, as I am, that I might answer him,
    that we should come to trial together.
speaker: Narrator

text:
There is no mediator between us,
    who might lay his hand on us both.
speaker: Narrator

text:
If he would take his rod away from me
    and not let dread of him terrify me,
speaker: Narrator

text:
then I would speak without fear of him,
    for I know I am not what I am thought to be.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
I will say to God, ‘Do not condemn me;
    let me know why you contend against me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Does it seem good to you to oppress,
    to despise the work of your hands
    and favor the schemes of the wicked?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Do you have eyes of flesh?
    Do you see as humans see?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Are your days like the days of mortals
    or your years like human years,
speaker: Narrator

text:
that you seek out my iniquity
    and search for my sin,
speaker: Narrator

text:
although you know that I am not guilty,
    and there is no one to deliver out of your hand?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Your hands fashioned and made me,
    and now you turn and destroy me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Remember that you fashioned me like clay,
    and will you turn me to dust again?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Did you not pour me out like milk
    and curdle me like cheese?
speaker: Narrator

text:
You clothed me with skin and flesh
    and knit me together with bones and sinews.
speaker: Narrator

speaker: Narrator
