They will suck the poison of asps;
    the tongue of a viper will kill them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They will not look on the rivers,
    the streams flowing with honey and curds.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They will give back the fruit of their toil
    and will not swallow it down;
from the profit of their trading
    they will get no enjoyment.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For they have crushed and abandoned the poor;
    they have seized a house that they did not build.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“For they knew no quiet in their bellies;
    in their greed they let nothing escape.
speaker: Narrator

text:
There was nothing left after they had eaten;
    therefore their prosperity will not endure.
speaker: Narrator

text:
In full sufficiency they will be in distress;
    all the force of misery will come upon them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
To fill their belly to the full,
    God will send his fierce anger into them
    and rain it upon them as their food.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They will flee from an iron weapon;
    a bronze arrow will strike them through.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator
Narrator

text:
The heavens will reveal their iniquity,
    and the earth will rise up against them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The possessions of their house will be carried away,
    dragged off in the day of God’s wrath.
speaker: Narrator

text:
This is the portion of the wicked from God,
    the heritage decreed for them by God.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Job answered:
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Listen carefully to my words,
    and let this be your consolation.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Bear with me, and I will speak;
    then after I have spoken, mock on.
speaker: Narrator

text:
As for me, is my complaint addressed to mortals?
    Why should I not be impatient?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Look at me and be appalled,
    and lay your hand upon your mouth.
speaker: Narrator

text:
When I think of it I am dismayed,
    and shuddering seizes my flesh.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Why do the wicked live on,
    reach old age, and grow mighty in power?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Their children are established in their presence
    and their offspring before their eyes.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Their houses are safe from fear,
    and no rod of God is upon them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Their bull breeds without fail;
    their cow calves and never miscarries.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They send out their little ones like a flock,
    and their children dance around.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They sing to the tambourine and the lyre
    and rejoice to the sound of the pipe.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They spend their days in prosperity,
    and in peace they go down to Sheol.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They say to God, ‘Leave us alone!
    We do not desire to know your ways.
speaker: Narrator

text:
What is the Almighty, that we should serve him?
    And what profit do we get if we pray to him?’
speaker: Narrator

text:
Is not their prosperity indeed their own achievement?
    The plans of the wicked are repugnant to me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“How often is the lamp of the wicked put out?
    How often does calamity come upon them?
    How often does God distribute pains in his anger?
speaker: Narrator

text:
How often are they like straw before the wind
    and like chaff that the storm carries away?
speaker: Narrator

text:
You say, ‘God stores up their iniquity for their children.’
    Let it be paid back to them, so that they may know it.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Let their own eyes see their destruction,
    and let them drink of the wrath of the Almighty.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For what do they care for their household after them,
    when the number of their months is cut off?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Will any teach God knowledge,
    seeing that he judges those who are on high?
speaker: Narrator

text:
One dies in full prosperity,
    being wholly at ease and secure,
speaker: Narrator

text:
his loins full of milk
    and the marrow of his bones moist.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Another dies in bitterness of soul,
    never having tasted of good.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They lie down alike in the dust,
    and the worms cover them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Oh, I know your thoughts
    and your schemes to wrong me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For you say, ‘Where is the house of the prince?
    Where is the tent in which the wicked lived?’
speaker: Narrator

text:
Have you not asked those who travel the roads,
    and do you not accept their testimony,
speaker: Narrator

text:
that the wicked are spared in the day of calamity
    and are rescued in the day of wrath?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Who declares their way to their face,
    and who repays them for what they have done?
speaker: Narrator

text:
When they are carried to the grave,
    a watch is kept over their tomb.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
How then will you comfort me with empty nothings?
    There is nothing left of your answers but falsehood.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Eliphaz the Temanite answered:
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Can a mortal be of use to God?
    Can even the wisest be of service to him?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Is it any pleasure to the Almighty if you are righteous,
    or is it gain to him if you make your ways blameless?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Is it for your piety that he reproves you
    and enters into judgment with you?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Is not your wickedness great?
    There is no end to your iniquities.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For you have exacted pledges from your family for no reason
    and stripped the naked of their clothing.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You have given no water to the weary to drink,
    and you have withheld bread from the hungry.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The powerful possess the land,
    and the favored live in it.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You have sent widows away empty-handed,
    and the arms of the orphans you have crushed.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Therefore snares are around you,
    and sudden terror overwhelms you,
speaker: Narrator

text:
or darkness so that you cannot see;
    a flood of water covers you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Is not God high in the heavens?
    See the highest stars, how lofty they are!
speaker: Narrator

text:
Therefore you say, ‘What does God know?
    Can he judge through the deep darkness?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Thick clouds enwrap him, so that he does not see,
    and he walks on the dome of heaven.’
speaker: Narrator

text:
Will you keep to the old way
    that the wicked have trod?
speaker: Narrator

text:
They were snatched away before their time;
    their foundation was washed away by a flood.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They said to God, ‘Leave us alone,’
    and ‘What can the Almighty do to us?’
speaker: Narrator

text:
Yet he filled their houses with good things—
    but the plans of the wicked are repugnant to me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The righteous see it and are glad;
    the innocent laugh them to scorn,
speaker: Narrator

text:
saying, ‘Surely our adversaries are cut off,
    and what they left, the fire has consumed.’
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Agree with God, and be at peace;
    in this way good will come to you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Receive instruction from his mouth,
    and lay up his words in your heart.
speaker: Narrator

text:
If you return to the Almighty, you will be restored,
    if you remove unrighteousness from your tents,
speaker: Narrator

text:
if you treat gold like dust
    and gold of Ophir like the stones of the torrent bed,
speaker: Narrator

text:
and if the Almighty is your gold
    and your precious silver,
speaker: Narrator

text:
then you will delight yourself in the Almighty
    and lift up your face to God.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You will pray to him, and he will hear you,
    and you will pay your vows.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You will decide on a matter, and it will be established for you,
    and light will shine on your ways.
speaker: Narrator

text:
When others are humiliated, you say it is pride,
    for he saves the humble.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He will deliver even those who are guilty;
    they will escape because of the cleanness of your hands.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Job answered:
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Today also my complaint is bitter;
    his hand is heavy despite my groaning.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Oh, that I knew where I might find him,
    that I might come even to his dwelling!
speaker: Narrator

text:
I would lay my case before him
    and fill my mouth with arguments.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I would learn what he would answer me
    and understand what he would say to me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Would he contend with me in the greatness of his power?
    No, but he would give heed to me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
There the upright could reason with him,
    and I should be acquitted forever by my judge.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“If I go forward, he is not there;
    or backward, I cannot perceive him;
speaker: Narrator

text:
on the left he hides, and I cannot behold him;
    I turn to the right, but I cannot see him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
But he knows the way that I take;
    when he has tested me, I shall come out like gold.
speaker: Narrator

text:
My foot has held fast to his steps;
    I have kept his way and have not turned aside.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I have not departed from the commandment of his lips;
    I have treasured his words in my bosom.
speaker: Narrator

text:
But he stands alone, and who can dissuade him?
    What he desires, that he does.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For he will complete what he appoints for me,
    and many such things are in his mind.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Therefore I am terrified at his presence;
    when I consider, I am in dread of him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
God has made my heart faint;
    the Almighty has terrified me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
If only I could vanish in darkness,
    and thick darkness would cover my face!
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Why are times not kept by the Almighty,
    and why do those who know him never see his days?
speaker: Narrator

text:
The wicked remove landmarks;
    they seize flocks and pasture them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They drive away the donkey of the orphan;
    they take the widow’s ox for a pledge.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They thrust the needy off the road;
    the poor of the earth all hide themselves.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Like wild asses in the desert
    they go out to their toil,
scavenging in the wasteland
    food for their young.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They reap in a field not their own,
    and they glean in the vineyard of the wicked.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They lie all night naked, without clothing,
    and have no covering in the cold.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They are wet with the rain of the mountains
    and cling to the rock for want of shelter.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“There are those who snatch the orphan child from the breast
    and take as a pledge the infant of the poor.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They go about naked, without clothing;
    though hungry, they carry the sheaves;
speaker: Narrator

text:
between their terraces they press out oil;
    they tread the winepresses but suffer thirst.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
“There are those who rebel against the light,
    who are not acquainted with its ways
    and do not stay in its paths.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The murderer rises at dusk
    to kill the poor and needy
    and in the night is like a thief.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The eye of the adulterer also waits for the twilight,
    saying, ‘No eye will see me,’
    and he disguises his face.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
For deep darkness is morning to all of them;
    for they are friends with the terrors of deep darkness.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
Drought and heat snatch away the snow waters;
    so does Sheol those who have sinned.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
“They harm the childless woman
    and do no good to the widow.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Yet God prolongs the life of the mighty by his power;
    they rise up when they despair of life.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He gives them security, and they are supported;
    his eyes are upon their ways.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
If it is not so, who will prove me a liar
    and show that there is nothing in what I say?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Bildad the Shuhite answered:
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Dominion and fear are with God;
    he makes peace in his high heaven.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Is there any number to his armies?
    Upon whom does his light not arise?
speaker: Narrator

text:
How then can a mortal be righteous before God?
    How can one born of woman be pure?
speaker: Narrator

text:
If even the moon is not bright
    and the stars are not pure in his sight,
speaker: Narrator

text:
how much less a mortal, who is a maggot,
    and a human being, who is a worm!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Job answered:
speaker: Narrator

text:
“How you have helped one who has no power!
    How you have assisted the arm that has no strength!
speaker: Narrator

text:
How you have counseled one who has no wisdom
    and given much good advice!
speaker: Narrator

text:
With whose help have you uttered words,
    and whose spirit has come forth from you?
speaker: Narrator

text:
The shades below tremble,
    the waters and their inhabitants.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Sheol is naked before God,
    and Abaddon has no covering.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He stretches out Zaphon over the void
    and hangs the earth upon nothing.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He binds up the waters in his thick clouds,
    and the cloud is not torn open by them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He covers the face of the full moon
    and spreads over it his cloud.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He has described a circle on the face of the waters,
    at the boundary between light and darkness.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The pillars of heaven tremble
    and are astounded at his rebuke.
speaker: Narrator

text:
By his power he stilled the Sea;
    by his understanding he struck down Rahab.
speaker: Narrator

text:
By his wind the heavens were made fair;
    his hand pierced the fleeing serpent.
speaker: Narrator

text:
These are indeed but the outskirts of his ways,
    and how small a whisper do we hear of him!
    But the thunder of his power who can understand?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Job again took up his discourse and said:
speaker: Narrator

text:
“As God lives, who has taken away my right,
    and the Almighty, who has made my soul bitter,
speaker: Narrator

text:
as long as my breath is in me
    and the spirit of God is in my nostrils,
speaker: Narrator

text:
my lips will not speak falsehood,
    and my tongue will not utter deceit.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Far be it from me to say that you are right;
    until I die I will not put away my integrity from me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I hold fast my righteousness and will not let it go;
    my heart will not reproach me as long as I live.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“May my enemy be like the wicked,
    and may my opponent be like the unrighteous.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For what is the hope of the godless when God cuts them off,
    when God takes away their lives?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Will God hear their cry
    when trouble comes upon them?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Will they take delight in the Almighty?
    Will they call upon God at all times?
speaker: Narrator

text:
I will teach you concerning the hand of God;
    that which is with the Almighty I will not conceal.
speaker: Narrator

text:
All of you have seen it yourselves;
    why then have you become altogether vain?
speaker: Narrator

text:
“This is the portion of the wicked with God
    and the heritage that oppressors receive from the Almighty:
speaker: Narrator

text:
If their children are multiplied, it is for the sword,
    and their offspring have not enough to eat.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Those who survive them the pestilence buries,
    and their widows make no lamentation.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Though they heap up silver like dust
    and pile up clothing like clay,
speaker: Narrator

text:
they may pile it up, but the just will wear it,
    and the innocent will divide the silver.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They build their houses like nests,
    like booths made by sentinels of the vineyard.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They go to bed with wealth but will do so no more;
    they open their eyes, and it is gone.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Terrors overtake them like a flood;
    in the night a whirlwind carries them off.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The east wind lifts them up, and they are gone;
    it sweeps them out of their place.
speaker: Narrator

text:
It hurls at them without pity;
    they flee from its power in headlong flight.
speaker: Narrator

text:
It claps its hands at them
    and hisses at them from its place.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Surely there is a mine for silver
    and a place for gold to be refined.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Iron is taken out of the earth,
    and copper is smelted from ore.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Miners put an end to darkness
    and search out to the farthest bound
    the ore in gloom and deep darkness.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
As for the earth, out of it comes bread,
    but underneath it is turned up as by fire.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Its stones are the place of sapphires,
    and its dust contains gold.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“That path no bird of prey knows,
    and the falcon’s eye has not seen it.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The proud wild animals have not trodden it;
    the lion has not passed over it.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“They put their hand to the flinty rock
    and overturn mountains by the roots.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They cut out channels in the rocks,
    and their eyes see every precious thing.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The sources of the rivers they probe;
    hidden things they bring to light.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“But where shall wisdom be found?
    And where is the place of understanding?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Mortals do not know the way to it,
    and it is not found in the land of the living.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The deep says, ‘It is not in me,’
    and the sea says, ‘It is not with me.’
speaker: Narrator

text:
It cannot be gotten for gold,
    and silver cannot be weighed out as its price.
speaker: Narrator

text:
It cannot be valued in the gold of Ophir,
    in precious onyx or sapphire.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Gold and glass cannot equal it,
    nor can it be exchanged for jewels of fine gold.
speaker: Narrator

text:
No mention shall be made of coral or of crystal;
    the price of wisdom is above pearls.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The chrysolite of Cush cannot compare with it,
    nor can it be valued in pure gold.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Where then does wisdom come from?
    And where is the place of understanding?
speaker: Narrator

text:
It is hidden from the eyes of all living
    and concealed from the birds of the air.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Abaddon and Death say,
    ‘We have heard a rumor of it with our ears.’
speaker: Narrator

text:
“God understands the way to it,
    and he knows its place.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For he looks to the ends of the earth
    and sees everything under the heavens.
speaker: Narrator

text:
When he gave to the wind its weight
    and apportioned out the waters by measure,
speaker: Narrator

text:
when he made a decree for the rain,
    and a way for the thunderbolt,
speaker: Narrator

text:
then he saw it and declared it;
    he established it and searched it out.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text: Job again took up his discourse and said:
speaker: Narrator

text:
“O that I were as in the months of old,
    as in the days when God watched over me,
speaker: Narrator

text:
when his lamp shone over my head,
    and by his light I walked through darkness,
speaker: Narrator

text:
when I was in my prime,
    when the friendship of God was upon my tent,
speaker: Narrator

text:
when the Almighty was still with me,
    when my children were around me,
speaker: Narrator

text:
when my steps were washed with milk
    and the rock poured out for me streams of oil!
speaker: Narrator

text:
When I went out to the gate of the city,
    when I took my seat in the square,
speaker: Narrator

text:
the young men saw me and withdrew,
    and the aged rose up and stood;
speaker: Narrator

text:
the nobles refrained from talking
    and laid their hands on their mouths;
speaker: Narrator

text:
the voices of princes were hushed,
    and their tongues stuck to the roofs of their mouths.
speaker: Narrator

text:
When the ear heard, it commended me,
    and when the eye saw, it approved,
speaker: Narrator

text:
because I delivered the poor who cried
    and the orphan who had no helper.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The blessing of the wretched came upon me,
    and I caused the widow’s heart to sing for joy.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I put on righteousness, and it clothed me;
    my justice was like a robe and a turban.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I was eyes to the blind
    and feet to the lame.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I was a father to the needy,
    and I championed the cause of the stranger.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I broke the fangs of the unrighteous
    and made them drop their prey from their teeth.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then I thought, ‘I shall die in my nest,
    and I shall multiply my days like the phoenix;
speaker: Narrator

text:
my roots spread out to the waters,
    with the dew all night on my branches;
speaker: Narrator

text:
my glory was fresh with me
    and my bow ever new in my hand.’
speaker: Narrator

text:
“They listened to me and waited
    and kept silence for my counsel.
speaker: Narrator

text:
After I spoke they did not speak again,
    and my word dropped upon them like dew.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They waited for me as for the rain;
    they opened their mouths as for the spring rain.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I smiled on them when they had no confidence,
    and the light of my countenance they did not extinguish.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I chose what they should do and sat as chief,
    and I lived like a king among his troops,
    like one who comforts mourners.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“But now they make sport of me,
    those who are younger than I,
whose fathers I would have disdained
    to set with the dogs of my flock.
speaker: Narrator

text:
What could I gain from the strength of their hands?
    All their vigor is gone.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Through want and hard hunger
    they gnaw the dry and desolate ground;
speaker: Narrator

text:
they pick mallow and the leaves of bushes
    and to warm themselves the roots of broom.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They are driven out from society;
    people shout after them as after a thief.
speaker: Narrator

text:
In the gullies of wadis they must live,
    in holes in the ground and in the rocks.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Among the bushes they bray;
    under the nettles they huddle together.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A senseless, disreputable brood,
    they have been whipped out of the land.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“And now they mock me in song;
    I am a byword to them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They abhor me; they keep aloof from me;
    they do not hesitate to spit at the sight of me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Because God has loosed my bowstring and humbled me,
    they have cast off restraint in my presence.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator
Narrator

text:
As through a wide breach they come;
    amid the crash they roll on.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
“And now my soul is poured out within me;
    days of affliction have taken hold of me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The night racks my bones,
    and the pain that gnaws me takes no rest.
speaker: Narrator

text:
With violence he seizes my garment;
    he grasps me by the collar of my tunic.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He has cast me into the mire,
    and I have become like dust and ashes.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I cry to you, and you do not answer me;
    I stand, and you merely look at me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You have turned cruel to me;
    with the might of your hand you persecute me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You lift me up on the wind, you make me ride on it,
    and you toss me about in the roar of the storm.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I know that you will bring me to death,
    to the house appointed for all living.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Surely one does not turn against the needy,
    when in disaster they cry for help.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Did I not weep for those whose day was hard?
    Was not my soul grieved for the poor?
speaker: Narrator

text:
But when I looked for good, evil came,
    and when I waited for light, darkness came.
speaker: Narrator

text:
My inward parts are in turmoil and are never still;
    days of affliction come to meet me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I go about in sunless gloom;
    I stand up in the assembly and cry for help.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I am a brother of jackals
    and a companion of ostriches.
speaker: Narrator

text:
My skin turns black and falls from me,
    and my bones burn with heat.
speaker: Narrator

text:
My lyre is turned to mourning
    and my pipe to the voice of those who weep.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“I have made a covenant with my eyes;
    how, then, could I look upon a virgin?
speaker: Narrator

text:
What would be my portion from God above
    and my heritage from the Almighty on high?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Does not calamity befall the unrighteous
    and disaster the workers of iniquity?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Does he not see my ways
    and number all my steps?
speaker: Narrator

text:
“If I have walked with falsehood,
    and my foot has hurried to deceit—
speaker: Narrator

text:
let me be weighed in a just balance,
    and let God know my integrity!—
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
then let me sow and another eat,
    and let what grows for me be rooted out.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“If my heart has been enticed by a woman
    and I have lain in wait at my neighbor’s door,
speaker: Narrator

text:
then let my wife grind for another,
    and let other men kneel over her.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For that would be a heinous crime;
    that would be a criminal offense;
speaker: Narrator

text:
for that would be a fire consuming down to Abaddon,
    and it would burn to the root all my harvest.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“If I have rejected the cause of my male or female slaves,
    when they brought a complaint against me,
speaker: Narrator

text:
what then shall I do when God rises up?
    When he makes inquiry, what shall I answer him?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Did not he who made me in the womb make them?
    And did not one fashion us in the womb?
speaker: Narrator

text:
“If I have withheld anything that the poor desired
    or have caused the eyes of the widow to fail
speaker: Narrator

text:
or have eaten my morsel alone
    and the orphan has not eaten from it—
speaker: Narrator

text:
for from my youth I reared the orphan like a father,
    and from my mother’s womb I guided the widow—
speaker: Narrator

text:
if I have seen anyone perish for lack of clothing
    or a poor person without covering,
speaker: Narrator

text:
whose loins have not blessed me,
    and who was not warmed with the fleece of my sheep;
speaker: Narrator

text:
if I have raised my hand against the orphan
    because I saw I had supporters at the gate;
speaker: Narrator

text:
then let my shoulder blade fall from my shoulder,
    and let my arm be broken from its socket.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For I was in terror of calamity from God,
    and I could not have faced his majesty.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“If I have made gold my trust
    or called fine gold my confidence,
speaker: Narrator

text:
if I have rejoiced because my wealth was great
    or because my hand had gotten much,
speaker: Narrator

text:
if I have looked at the sun when it shone
    or the moon moving in splendor,
speaker: Narrator

text:
and my heart has been secretly enticed,
    and my mouth has kissed my hand,
speaker: Narrator

text:
this also would be an iniquity to be punished by the judges,
    for I should have been false to God above.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“If I have rejoiced at the ruin of those who hated me
    or exulted when evil overtook them—
speaker: Narrator

text:
I have not let my mouth sin
    by asking for their lives with a curse—
speaker: Narrator

text:
if those of my tent ever said,
    ‘O that we might be sated with his flesh!’—
speaker: Narrator

text:
the stranger has not lodged in the street;
    I have opened my doors to the traveler—
speaker: Narrator

text:
if I have concealed my transgressions as others do,
    by hiding my iniquity in my bosom,
speaker: Narrator

text:
because I stood in great fear of the multitude,
    and the contempt of families terrified me,
    so that I kept silence and did not go out of doors—
speaker: Narrator

text:
O that I had one to hear me!
    (Here is my signature! Let the Almighty answer me!)
    O that I had the indictment written by my adversary!
speaker: Narrator

text:
Surely I would carry it on my shoulder;
    I would bind it on me like a crown;
speaker: Narrator

text:
I would give him an account of all my steps;
    like a prince I would approach him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“If my land has cried out against me
    and its furrows have wept together,
speaker: Narrator

text:
if I have eaten its yield without payment
    and caused the death of its owners,
speaker: Narrator

text:
let thorns grow instead of wheat
    and foul weeds instead of barley.”
The words of Job are ended.
speaker: Narrator

text: So these three men ceased to answer Job, because he was righteous in his own eyes.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Elihu son of Barachel the Buzite, of the family of Ram, became angry. He was angry at Job because he justified himself rather than God;
speaker: Narrator

text: he was angry also at Job’s three friends because they had found no answer, though they had declared Job to be in the wrong.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now Elihu had waited to speak to Job because they were older than he.
speaker: Narrator

text: But when Elihu saw that there was no answer in the mouths of these three men, he became angry.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Elihu son of Barachel the Buzite answered:
“I am young in years,
    and you are aged;
therefore I was timid and afraid
    to declare my opinion to you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I said, ‘Let days speak
    and many years teach wisdom.’
speaker: Narrator

text:
But truly it is the spirit in a mortal,
    the breath of the Almighty that makes for understanding.
speaker: Narrator

text:
It is not the old who are wise
    nor the aged who understand what is right.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Therefore I say, ‘Listen to me;
    let me also declare my opinion.’
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
I gave you my attention,
    but there was, in fact, no one who confuted Job,
    no one among you who answered his words.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Yet do not say, ‘We have found wisdom;
    God may vanquish him, not a human.’
speaker: Narrator

text:
He has not directed his words against me,
    and I will not answer him with your speeches.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“They are dismayed; they answer no more;
    they have not a word to say.
speaker: Narrator

text:
And am I to wait because they do not speak,
    because they stand there and answer no more?
speaker: Narrator

text:
I also will give my answer;
    I also will declare my opinion.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For I am full of words;
    the spirit within me constrains me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
My belly is indeed like wine that has no vent;
    like new wineskins, it is ready to burst.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I must speak, so that I may find relief;
    I must open my lips and answer.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I will not show partiality to any person
    or use flattery toward anyone.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For I do not know how to flatter—
    or my Maker would soon put an end to me!
speaker: Narrator

text:
“But now, hear my speech, O Job,
    and listen to all my words.
speaker: Narrator

text:
See, I open my mouth;
    the tongue in my mouth speaks.
speaker: Narrator

text:
My words declare the uprightness of my heart,
    and what my lips know they speak sincerely.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The spirit of God has made me,
    and the breath of the Almighty gives me life.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Answer me, if you can;
    set your words in order before me; take your stand.
speaker: Narrator

text:
See, before God I am as you are;
    I, too, was formed from a piece of clay.
speaker: Narrator

text:
No fear of me need terrify you;
    my pressure will not be heavy on you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Surely, you have spoken in my hearing,
    and I have heard the sound of your words.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You say, ‘I am clean, without transgression;
    I am pure, and there is no iniquity in me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Look, he finds occasions against me;
    he counts me as his enemy;
speaker: Narrator

text:
he puts my feet in the stocks
    and watches all my paths.’
speaker: Narrator

text:
“But in this you are not right. I will answer you:
    God is greater than any mortal.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Why do you contend against him,
    saying, ‘He will answer none of my words’?
speaker: Narrator

text:
For God speaks in one way
    and in two, though people do not perceive it.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
then he opens their ears
    and terrifies them with warnings,
speaker: Narrator

text:
that he may turn them aside from their deeds
    and keep them from pride,
speaker: Narrator

text:
to spare their souls from the Pit,
    their lives from traversing the River.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They are also chastened with pain upon their beds
    and with continual strife in their bones,
speaker: Narrator

text:
so that their lives loathe bread
    and their appetites dainty food.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Their flesh is so wasted away that it cannot be seen,
    and their bones, once invisible, now stick out.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Their souls draw near the Pit
    and their lives to those who bring death.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then, if there should be for one of them an angel,
    a mediator, one of a thousand,
    one who declares a person upright,
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
let his flesh become fresh with youth;
    let him return to the days of his youthful vigor,’
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
That person sings to others and says,
‘I sinned and perverted what was right,
    and it was not paid back to me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He has redeemed my soul from going down to the Pit,
    and my life shall see the light.’
speaker: Narrator

text:
“God indeed does all these things,
    twice, three times, with mortals,
speaker: Narrator

text:
to bring back their souls from the Pit,
    so that they may see the light of life.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Pay heed, Job, listen to me;
    be silent, and I will speak.
speaker: Narrator

text:
If you have anything to say, answer me;
    speak, for I desire to justify you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
If not, listen to me;
    be silent, and I will teach you wisdom.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Elihu continued and said:
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Hear my words, you wise men,
    and give ear to me, you who know,
speaker: Narrator

text:
for the ear tests words
    as the palate tastes food.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Let us choose what is right;
    let us determine among ourselves what is good.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For Job has said, ‘I am innocent,
    and God has taken away my right;
speaker: Narrator

text:
in spite of being right I am counted a liar;
    my wound is incurable, though I am without transgression.’
speaker: Narrator

text:
Who is there like Job,
    who drinks up scoffing like water,
speaker: Narrator

text:
who goes in company with evildoers
    and walks with the wicked?
speaker: Narrator

text:
For he has said, ‘It profits one nothing
    to take delight in God.’
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
For according to their deeds he will repay them,
    and according to their ways he will make it befall them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Of a truth, God will not do wickedly,
    and the Almighty will not pervert justice.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Who gave him charge over the earth,
    and who laid on him the whole world?
speaker: Narrator

text:
If he should take back his spirit to himself
    and gather to himself his breath,
speaker: Narrator

text:
all flesh would perish together,
    and all mortals return to dust.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“If you have understanding, hear this;
    listen to what I say.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Shall one who hates justice govern?
    Will you condemn one who is righteous and mighty,
speaker: Narrator

text:
who says to a king, ‘You scoundrel!’
    and to princes, ‘You wicked men!’;
speaker: Narrator

text:
who shows no partiality to nobles,
    nor regards the rich more than the poor,
    for they are all the work of his hands?
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
“For his eyes are upon the ways of mortals,
    and he sees all their steps.
speaker: Narrator

text:
There is no gloom or deep darkness
    where evildoers may hide themselves.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For he has not appointed a time for anyone
    to go before God in judgment.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He shatters the mighty without investigation
    and sets others in their place.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Thus, knowing their works,
    he overturns them in the night, and they are crushed.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He strikes them for their wickedness
    while others look on,
speaker: Narrator

text:
because they turned aside from following him
    and had no regard for any of his ways,
speaker: Narrator

text:
so that they caused the cry of the poor to come to him,
    and he heard the cry of the afflicted—
speaker: Narrator

text:
When he is quiet, who can condemn?
    When he hides his face, who can behold him?
    Whether nation or person, it is the same—
speaker: Narrator

text:
so that the godless should not reign
    or those who ensnare the people.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“For has anyone said to God,
    ‘I have endured punishment; I will not offend any more;
speaker: Narrator

text:
teach me what I do not see;
    if I have done iniquity, I will do it no more’?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Will he then pay back to suit you
    because you reject it?
For you must choose and not I;
    therefore declare what you know.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Those who have sense will say to me,
    and the wise who hear me will say,
speaker: Narrator

text:
‘Job speaks without knowledge;
    his words are without insight.’
speaker: Narrator

text:
Would that Job were tried to the limit,
    because his answers are those of the wicked.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text: Elihu continued and said:
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Do you think this to be just?
    You say, ‘I am in the right before God.’
speaker: Narrator

text:
If you ask, ‘What advantage have I?
    How am I better off than if I had sinned?’
speaker: Narrator

text:
I will answer you
    and your friends with you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Look at the heavens and see;
    observe the clouds, which are higher than you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
If you have sinned, what do you accomplish against him?
    And if your transgressions are multiplied, what do you do to him?
speaker: Narrator

text:
If you are righteous, what do you give to him,
    or what does he receive from your hand?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Your wickedness affects others like you,
    and your righteousness, other human beings.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Because of the multitude of oppressions people cry out;
    they call for help because of the arm of the mighty.
speaker: Narrator

text:
But no one says, ‘Where is God my Maker,
    who gives strength in the night,
speaker: Narrator

text:
who teaches us more than the animals of the earth
    and makes us wiser than the birds of the air?’
speaker: Narrator

text:
There they cry out, but he does not answer,
    because of the pride of evildoers.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Surely God does not hear an empty cry,
    nor does the Almighty regard it.
speaker: Narrator

text:
How much less when you say that you do not see him,
    that the case is before him and you are waiting for him!
speaker: Narrator

text:
And now, because his anger does not punish
    and he does not greatly heed transgression,
speaker: Narrator

text:
Job opens his mouth in empty talk;
    he multiplies words without knowledge.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Elihu continued and said:
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Bear with me a little, and I will show you,
    for I have yet something to say on God’s behalf.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I will bring my knowledge from far away
    and ascribe righteousness to my Maker.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For truly my words are not false;
    one who is perfect in knowledge is with you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Surely God is mighty and does not despise any;
    he is mighty in strength of understanding.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He does not keep the wicked alive
    but gives the afflicted their right.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He does not withdraw his eyes from the righteous,
    but with kings on the throne
    he sets them forever, and they are exalted.
speaker: Narrator

text:
And if they are bound in fetters
    and caught in the cords of affliction,
speaker: Narrator

text:
then he declares to them their work
    and their transgressions, that they are behaving arrogantly.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He opens their ears to instruction
    and commands that they return from iniquity.
speaker: Narrator

text:
If they listen and serve him,
    they complete their days in prosperity
    and their years in pleasantness.
speaker: Narrator

text:
But if they do not listen, they shall perish by the sword
    and die without knowledge.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“The godless in heart cherish anger;
    they do not cry for help when he binds them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They die in their youth,
    and their life ends in shame.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He delivers the afflicted by their affliction
    and opens their ear by adversity.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He also allured you out of distress
    into a broad place where there was no constraint,
    and what was set on your table was full of fatness.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“But you are obsessed with the case of the wicked;
    judgment and justice seize you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Beware that wrath does not entice you into scoffing,
    and do not let the greatness of the ransom turn you aside.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Will your cry avail to keep you from distress,
    or will all the force of your strength?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Do not long for the night,
    when peoples are cut off in their place.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Beware! Do not turn to iniquity;
    because of that you have been tried by affliction.
speaker: Narrator

text:
See, God is exalted in his power;
    who is a teacher like him?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Who has prescribed for him his way,
    or who can say, ‘You have done wrong’?
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Remember to extol his work,
    of which mortals have sung.
speaker: Narrator

text:
All people have looked on it;
    everyone watches it from far away.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Surely God is great, and we do not know him;
    the number of his years is unsearchable.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For he draws up the drops of water;
    he distills his mist in rain,
speaker: Narrator

text:
which the skies pour down
    and drop upon mortals abundantly.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Can anyone understand the spreading of the clouds,
    the thunderings of his pavilion?
speaker: Narrator

text:
See, he scatters his lightning around him
    and covers the roots of the sea.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For by these he governs peoples;
    he gives food in abundance.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He covers his hands with the lightning
    and commands it to strike the mark.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Its crashing tells about him;
    he is jealous with anger against iniquity.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“At this also my heart trembles
    and leaps out of its place.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Listen, listen to the thunder of his voice
    and the rumbling that comes from his mouth.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Under the whole heaven he lets it loose,
    and his lightning to the corners of the earth.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
God thunders wondrously with his voice;
    he does great things that we cannot comprehend.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For to the snow he says, ‘Fall on the earth’;
    and the shower of rain, his heavy shower of rain,
speaker: Narrator

text:
serves as a sign on everyone’s hand,
    so that all whom he has made may know it.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then the animals go into their lairs
    and remain in their dens.
speaker: Narrator

text:
From its chamber comes the whirlwind
    and cold from the scattering winds.
speaker: Narrator

text:
By the breath of God ice is given,
    and the broad waters are frozen fast.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He loads the thick cloud with moisture;
    the clouds scatter his lightning.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They turn round and round by his guidance
    to accomplish all that he commands them
    on the face of the habitable world.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Whether for correction or for his land
    or for love, he causes it to happen.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Hear this, O Job;
    stop and consider the wondrous works of God.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Do you know how God lays his command upon them
    and causes the lightning of his cloud to shine?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Do you know the balancings of the clouds,
    the wondrous works of the one whose knowledge is perfect,
speaker: Narrator

text:
you whose garments are hot
    when the earth is still because of the south wind?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Can you, like him, spread out the skies,
    hard as a molten mirror?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Teach us what we shall say to him;
    we cannot draw up our case because of darkness.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Should he be told that I want to speak?
    Did anyone ever wish to be swallowed up?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Now, no one can look on the light
    when it is bright in the skies,
    when the wind has passed and cleared them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Out of the north comes golden splendor;
    around God is awesome majesty.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
Therefore mortals fear him;
    he does not regard any who are wise in their own conceit.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord answered Job out of the whirlwind:
speaker: Narrator

text: “Who is this that darkens counsel by words without knowledge?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Gird up your loins like a man;
    I will question you, and you shall declare to me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Where were you when I laid the foundation of the earth?
    Tell me, if you have understanding.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Who determined its measurements—surely you know!
    Or who stretched the line upon it?
speaker: Narrator

text:
On what were its bases sunk,
    or who laid its cornerstone
speaker: Narrator

text:
when the morning stars sang together
    and all the heavenly beings shouted for joy?
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Or who shut in the sea with doors
    when it burst out from the womb,
speaker: Narrator

text:
when I made the clouds its garment
    and thick darkness its swaddling band,
speaker: Narrator

text:
and prescribed bounds for it,
    and set bars and doors,
speaker: Narrator

text:
and said, ‘Thus far shall you come and no farther,
    and here shall your proud waves be stopped’?
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Have you commanded the morning since your days began
    and caused the dawn to know its place,
speaker: Narrator

text:
so that it might take hold of the skirts of the earth,
    and the wicked be shaken out of it?
speaker: Narrator

text:
It is changed like clay under the seal,
    and it is dyed like a garment.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Light is withheld from the wicked,
    and their uplifted arm is broken.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Have you entered into the springs of the sea
    or walked in the recesses of the deep?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Have the gates of death been revealed to you,
    or have you seen the gates of deep darkness?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Have you comprehended the expanse of the earth?
    Declare, if you know all this.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Where is the way to the dwelling of light,
    and where is the place of darkness,
speaker: Narrator

text:
that you may take it to its territory
    and that you may discern the paths to its home?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Surely you know, for you were born then,
    and the number of your days is great!
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Have you entered the storehouses of the snow,
    or have you seen the storehouses of the hail,
speaker: Narrator

text:
which I have reserved for the time of trouble,
    for the day of battle and war?
speaker: Narrator

text:
What is the way to the place where the light is distributed
    or where the east wind is scattered upon the earth?
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Who has cut a channel for the torrents of rain
    and a way for the thunderbolt,
speaker: Narrator

text:
to bring rain on a land where no one lives,
    on the desert, which is empty of human life,
speaker: Narrator

text:
to satisfy the waste and desolate land,
    and to make the ground put forth grass?
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Has the rain a father,
    or who has fathered the drops of dew?
speaker: Narrator

text:
From whose womb did the ice come forth,
    and who has given birth to the hoarfrost of heaven?
speaker: Narrator

text:
The waters become hard like stone,
    and the face of the deep is frozen.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Can you bind the chains of the Pleiades
    or loose the cords of Orion?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Can you lead forth the Mazzaroth in their season,
    or can you guide the Bear with its children?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Do you know the ordinances of the heavens?
    Can you establish their rule on the earth?
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Can you lift up your voice to the clouds,
    so that a flood of waters may cover you?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Can you send forth lightnings, so that they may go
    and say to you, ‘Here we are’?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Who has put wisdom in the inward parts
    or given understanding to the mind?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Who has the wisdom to number the clouds?
    Or who can tilt the waterskins of the heavens
speaker: Narrator

text:
when the dust runs into a mass
    and the clods cling together?
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Can you hunt the prey for the lion
    or satisfy the appetite of the young lions,
speaker: Narrator

text:
when they crouch in their dens
    or lie in wait in their covert?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Who provides for the raven its prey,
    when its young ones cry to God
    and wander about for lack of food?
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Do you know when the mountain goats give birth?
    Do you observe the calving of the deer?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Can you number the months that they fulfill,
    and do you know the time when they give birth,
speaker: Narrator

text:
when they crouch to give birth to their offspring
    and are delivered of their young?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Their young ones become strong; they grow up in the open;
    they go forth and do not return to them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Who has let the wild ass go free?
    Who has loosed the bonds of the swift ass,
speaker: Narrator

text:
to which I have given the steppe for its home,
    the salt land for its dwelling place?
speaker: Narrator

text:
It scorns the tumult of the city;
    it does not hear the shouts of the driver.
speaker: Narrator

text:
It ranges the mountains as its pasture,
    and it searches after every green thing.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Is the wild ox willing to serve you?
    Will it spend the night at your crib?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Can you tie it in the furrow with ropes,
    or will it harrow the valleys after you?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Will you depend on it because its strength is great,
    and will you hand over your labor to it?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Do you have faith in it that it will return
    and bring your grain to your threshing floor?
speaker: Narrator

text:
“The ostrich’s wings flap wildly,
    though its pinions lack plumage.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For it leaves its eggs to the earth
    and lets them be warmed on the ground,
speaker: Narrator

text:
forgetting that a foot may crush them
    and that a wild animal may trample them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
It deals cruelly with its young, as if they were not its own;
    though its labor should be in vain, yet it has no fear;
speaker: Narrator

text:
because God has made it forget wisdom
    and given it no share in understanding.
speaker: Narrator

text:
When it spreads its plumes aloft,
    it laughs at the horse and its rider.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Do you give the horse its might?
    Do you clothe its neck with mane?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Do you make it leap like the locust?
    Its majestic snorting is terrible.
speaker: Narrator

text:
It paws violently, exults mightily;
    it goes out to meet the weapons.
speaker: Narrator

text:
It laughs at fear and is not dismayed;
    it does not turn back from the sword.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Upon it rattle the quiver,
    the flashing spear, and the javelin.
speaker: Narrator

text:
With fierceness and rage it swallows the ground;
    it cannot stand still at the sound of the trumpet.
speaker: Narrator

text:
When the trumpet sounds, it says ‘Aha!’
    From a distance it smells the battle,
    the thunder of the captains, and the shouting.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Is it by your wisdom that the hawk soars
    and spreads its wings toward the south?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Is it at your command that the eagle mounts up
    and makes its nest on high?
speaker: Narrator

text:
It lives on the rock and makes its home
    in the fastness of the rocky crag.
speaker: Narrator

text:
From there it spies the prey;
    its eyes see it from far away.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Its young ones suck up blood,
    and where the slain are, there it is.”
speaker: Narrator

text: And the Lord said to Job:
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Shall a faultfinder contend with the Almighty?
    Anyone who argues with God must respond.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Job answered the Lord:
speaker: Narrator

text:
“See, I am of small account; what shall I answer you?
    I lay my hand on my mouth.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I have spoken once, and I will not answer,
    twice but will proceed no further.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord answered Job out of the whirlwind:
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Gird up your loins like a man;
    I will question you, and you declare to me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Will you even put me in the wrong?
    Will you condemn me that you may be justified?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Have you an arm like God,
    and can you thunder with a voice like his?
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Deck yourself with majesty and dignity;
    clothe yourself with glory and splendor.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Pour out the overflowings of your anger,
    and look on all who are proud and humble them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Look on all who are proud and bring them low;
    tread down the wicked where they stand.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Hide them all in the dust together;
    bind their faces in the world below.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then I will also acknowledge to you
    that your own right hand can give you victory.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
Its strength is in its loins
    and its power in the muscles of its belly.
speaker: Narrator

text:
It makes its tail stiff like a cedar;
    the sinews of its thighs are knit together.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Its bones are tubes of bronze,
    its limbs like bars of iron.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“It is the first of the great acts of God;
    only its Maker can approach it with the sword.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For the mountains yield food for it
    where all the wild animals play.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Under the lotus plants it lies,
    in the covert of the reeds and in the marsh.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The lotus trees cover it for shade;
    the willows of the wadi surround it.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Even if the river is turbulent, it is not frightened;
    it is confident though Jordan rushes against its mouth.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Can one take it with hooks
    or pierce its nose with a snare?
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Can you draw out Leviathan with a fishhook
    or press down its tongue with a cord?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Can you put a rope in its nose
    or pierce its jaw with a hook?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Will it make many supplications to you?
    Will it speak soft words to you?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Will it make a covenant with you
    to be taken as your servant forever?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Will you play with it as with a bird
    or put it on a leash for your young women?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Will traders bargain over it?
    Will they divide it up among the merchants?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Can you fill its skin with harpoons
    or its head with fishing spears?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Lay hands on it;
    think of the battle; you will not do it again!
speaker: Narrator

text:
Any hope of capturing it will be disappointed;
    one is overwhelmed even at the sight of it.
speaker: Narrator

text:
No one is so fierce as to dare to stir it up.
    Who can stand before it?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Who can confront it and be safe?
    —under the whole heaven, who?
speaker: Narrator

text:
“I will not keep silent concerning its limbs
    or its mighty strength or its splendid frame.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Who can strip off its outer garment?
    Who can penetrate its double coat of mail?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Who can open the doors of its face?
    There is terror all around its teeth.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Its back is made of shields in rows,
    shut up closely as with a seal.
speaker: Narrator

text:
One is so near to another
    that no air can come between them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They are joined one to another;
    they clasp each other and cannot be separated.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Its sneezes flash forth light,
    and its eyes are like the eyelids of the dawn.
speaker: Narrator

text:
From its mouth go flaming torches;
    sparks of fire leap out.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Out of its nostrils comes smoke,
    as from a boiling pot and burning rushes.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Its breath kindles coals,
    and a flame comes out of its mouth.
speaker: Narrator

text:
In its neck abides strength,
    and terror dances before it.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The folds of its flesh cling together;
    it is firmly cast and immovable.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Its heart is as hard as stone,
    as hard as the lower millstone.
speaker: Narrator

text:
When it raises itself up the gods are afraid;
    at the crashing they are beside themselves.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Though the sword reaches it, it does not avail,
    nor does the spear, the dart, or the javelin.
speaker: Narrator

text:
It counts iron as straw
    and bronze as rotten wood.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The arrow cannot make it flee;
    slingstones, for it, are turned to chaff.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Clubs are counted as chaff;
    it laughs at the rattle of javelins.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Its underparts are like sharp potsherds;
    it spreads itself like a threshing sledge on the mire.
speaker: Narrator

text:
It makes the deep boil like a pot;
    it makes the sea like a pot of ointment.
speaker: Narrator

text:
It leaves a shining wake behind it;
    one would think the deep to be white-haired.
speaker: Narrator

text:
On earth it has no equal,
    a creature without fear.
speaker: Narrator

text:
It surveys everything that is lofty;
    it is king over all that are proud.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Job answered the Lord:
speaker: Narrator

text:
“I know that you can do all things
    and that no purpose of yours can be thwarted.
speaker: Narrator

text:
‘Who is this that hides counsel without knowledge?’
Therefore I have uttered what I did not understand,
    things too wonderful for me that I did not know.
speaker: Narrator

text:
‘Hear, and I will speak;
    I will question you, and you declare to me.’
speaker: Narrator

text:
I had heard of you by the hearing of the ear,
    but now my eye sees you;
speaker: Narrator

text:
therefore I despise myself
    and repent in dust and ashes.”
speaker: Narrator

text: After the Lord had spoken these words to Job, the Lord said to Eliphaz the Temanite: “My wrath is kindled against you and against your two friends, for you have not spoken of me what is right, as my servant Job has.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now therefore take seven bulls and seven rams, and go to my servant Job, and offer up for yourselves a burnt offering, and my servant Job shall pray for you, for I will accept his prayer not to deal with you according to your folly, for you have not spoken of me what is right, as my servant Job has done.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Eliphaz the Temanite and Bildad the Shuhite and Zophar the Naamathite went and did what the Lord had told them, and the Lord accepted Job’s prayer.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the Lord restored the fortunes of Job when he had prayed for his friends, and the Lord gave Job twice as much as he had before.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then there came to him all his brothers and sisters and all who had known him before, and they ate bread with him in his house; they showed him sympathy and comforted him for all the evil that the Lord had brought upon him; and each of them gave him a piece of money and a gold ring.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord blessed the latter days of Job more than his beginning, and he had fourteen thousand sheep, six thousand camels, a thousand yoke of oxen, and a thousand donkeys.
speaker: Narrator

text: He also had seven sons and three daughters.
speaker: Narrator

text: He named the first Jemimah, the second Keziah, and the third Keren-happuch.
speaker: Narrator

text: In all the land there were no women so beautiful as Job’s daughters, and their father gave them an inheritance along with their brothers.
speaker: Narrator

text: After this Job lived one hundred and forty years and saw his children and his children’s children, four generations.
speaker: Narrator

text: And Job died, old and full of days.
speaker: Narrator
